Article.ArticleTitle: Influence of water molecule on active sites of manganese oxide-based catalysts for ozone decomposition.

AbstractText: Developing an efficient approach to decompose ground-level O<sub>3</sub> in humidity is crucial for preventing O<sub>3</sub> pollution in practical application scenes. In this study, MnO<sub>x</sub>, CuO, and Cu/MnO<sub>x</sub> were synthesized to investigate the influence of H<sub>2</sub>O on the variation of active sites during O<sub>3</sub> decomposition. The structural characterizations of the as-synthetic catalysts were measured by N2 physisorption, XRD, SEM, O<sub>2</sub>-TPD, H<sub>2</sub>-TPR, TG, and FT-IR analyses. In dry conditions, the elimination rate of O<sub>3</sub> followed the sequence of MnO<sub>x</sub> > Cu/MnO<sub>x</sub> > CuO. The introduction of Cu to MnO<sub>x</sub> enhanced the surface area and pore volume of Cu/MnO<sub>x</sub>, accordingly diminishing the amounts of surface defects and the participation of sub-surface lattice oxygen for catalytic cycle, indicating that surface defects and oxygen vacancies (V<sub>O</sub>) determined the catalytic activity for O<sub>3</sub> decomposition. In humid conditions, the elimination rate of O<sub>3</sub> changed to the sequence of Cu/MnO<sub>x</sub> > MnO<sub>x</sub> > CuO, with a variation rate compared to dry conditions of -62.9% for MnO<sub>x</sub>, 14.2% for CuO, and 27.7% for Cu/MnO<sub>x</sub>. The decrease of participant sub-surface lattice oxygen and the accumulation of intermediates in humidity diminished the decomposition of O<sub>3</sub> on MnO<sub>x</sub>, while the active species such as superoxide radicals generating from the reaction of H<sub>2</sub>O and Cu/MnO<sub>x</sub> facilitated the participation of V<sub>O</sub> and the desorption of O<sub>2</sub> from the occupied active sites, accelerating the catalytic cycle on Cu/MnO<sub>x</sub>. This work developed a deeper understanding of the influence of H<sub>2</sub>O on catalytic activity, promoting the performance of MnO<sub>x</sub>-based catalysts for practical O<sub>3</sub> decomposition.
